head.title: New York Needs a State Smoking Law;Reason for Quitting

hedline.hl1: New York Needs a State Smoking Law;Reason for Quitting

block.p: Re "Leave the Smoking Ban Alone" (editorial, April 11):
Re "Leave the Smoking Ban Alone" (editorial, April 11):
You note that New Yorkers seem happy with the results of New York City's restaurant smoking restrictions.
The restrictions make eating out more comfortable for nonsmokers, put the reformed smoker at ease by eliminating the temptation to light up after a meal and eliminate the hazard of secondhand smoke.
In our clinical experience, however, the ban has not been an issue for people to begin a stop-smoking treatment. "I can't go to restaurants" is rarely heard as a reason for quitting.

Smokers referred to us for medical treatment admit, after careful probing, that fear of death prompted them to give up their best friend. The passing of a relative from lung disease, some chest pain that is suggestive of cardiac problems, or reaching age 30, 40 or 50 has awakened the concern with one's own mortality.
ELLIOT WINEBURG, M.D. New York, April 11, 1996
The writer, director of the Stop Smoking Medical Center, is an assistant clinical professor at Mount Sinai School of Medicine.
